bestBHT.bht: And your belief is sound: for I did indeed come forth from the Father, sent by Him, and entered into the world as the fulfillment of His pre-existent state. The connection with the preceding words is a summary of Jesus' history, from His eternal state with the Father to His ultimate return to Him. He came to lead us to the Father and goes to prepare a place for us in His house. Our faith in Him perceives His divine power, while our love contemplates the purpose and power of God in offering Him to us. Though He has left the world, His grace towards us remains in full force.

Henry Alford: 28.] ‘And your belief is sound: for I did indeed come forth’.... see ch. xiii. 3.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: I came forth from the Father, &c.—that is, 'And ye are right, for I have indeed so come forth, and shall soon return whence I came.'"
This echo of the truth, alluded to in John 16:27, seems like thinking aloud...
...as if it were grateful to His own spirit on such a subject and at such an hour.
Albert Barnes: I came forth from the Father - I came sent by the Father.
And am come into the world - See John 3:19; John 6:14, John 6:62; John 9:39.
Marvin Vincent: From the Father [παρα] . The best texts read, ejk, out of.
John Calvin: Our faith in him would not be steady, if it did not perceive his Divine power.
Our love ought to be of such a nature that our faith shall contemplate the purpose and power of God, by whose hand he is offered to us.
He therefore left the world when, laying aside our weaknesses, he was received into heaven; but his grace toward us is still in all its force.
Philip Schaff: The connection of this verse with the preceding is not to be found in the supposition that we have here additional mention made of two great truths in which the disciples are to rest.

The words before us are accordingly a summary of the whole history of Jesus in the light of His redeeming work, from the period of His pre-existent state in the bosom of the Father to the period when He shall again return to His everlasting rest in Him.
He came that He might lead men to the Father: He goes that they may be perfected in the Spirit, and that He may prepare a place for them in the many places of abode in the Father’s house.
Archibald T. Robertson: I came out from the Father (εξηλθον εκ του πατρος). Definite act (aorist), the Incarnation, with repetition of εκ (out of), while in verse John 16:27 we have παρα του πατρος εξηλθον) with no practical distinction between εκ and παρα in resultant idea.
Am come (εληλυθα). Perfect active indicative of ερχομα, as in John 18:37. The Incarnation is now a permanent fact, once only a blessed hope (John 11:27).
His leaving the world and going to the Father does not set aside the fact of the Incarnation. Both αφιημ (I leave) and πορευομα (I go) are futuristic present indicatives.
John Gill: This his coming forth from the Father is to be understood, not of his eternal filiation; nor of his coming forth in a way of grace towards his own people in the council and covenant of grace and peace; nor of his constitution, as Mediator, from everlasting; but of his coming in the flesh in the fulness of time."
And am come into the world; where he was before, as the Creator and upholder of it, by his immensity and powerful presence; this designs his coming and manifestation in the flesh.
Again, I leave the world; not that he relinquished the sustaining and government of it, as God, nor the care of his people in it, as Mediator, for whom he retains the same love as ever.
